speaker: ROMAN
text: I know you well, sir, and you know me. Your

speaker: ROMAN
text: name I think is Adrian.

speaker: VOLSCE
text: It is so, sir. Truly, I have forgot you.

speaker: ROMAN
text: I am a Roman, and my services are, as you are,

speaker: ROMAN
text: against ’em. Know you me yet?

speaker: VOLSCE
text: Nicanor, no?

speaker: ROMAN
text: The same, sir.

speaker: VOLSCE
text: You had more beard when I last saw you, but

speaker: VOLSCE
text: your favor is well approved by your tongue.

speaker: VOLSCE
text: What’s the news in Rome? I have a note from the

speaker: VOLSCE
text: Volscian state to find you out there. You have well

speaker: VOLSCE
text: saved me a day’s journey.

speaker: ROMAN
text: There hath been in Rome strange insurrections,

speaker: ROMAN
text: the people against the senators, patricians,

speaker: ROMAN
text: and nobles.

speaker: VOLSCE
text: Hath been? Is it ended, then? Our state thinks

speaker: VOLSCE
text: not so. They are in a most warlike preparation and

speaker: VOLSCE
text: hope to come upon them in the heat of their

speaker: VOLSCE
text: division.

speaker: ROMAN
text: The main blaze of it is past, but a small thing

speaker: ROMAN
text: would make it flame again; for the nobles receive

speaker: ROMAN
text: so to heart the banishment of that worthy Coriolanus

speaker: ROMAN
text: that they are in a ripe aptness to take all power

speaker: ROMAN
text: from the people and to pluck from them their tribunes

speaker: ROMAN
text: forever. This lies glowing, I can tell you, and

speaker: ROMAN
text: is almost mature for the violent breaking out.

speaker: VOLSCE
text: Coriolanus banished?

speaker: ROMAN
text: Banished, sir.

speaker: VOLSCE
text: You will be welcome with this intelligence,

speaker: VOLSCE
text: Nicanor.

speaker: ROMAN
text: The day serves well for them now. I have heard

speaker: ROMAN
text: it said the fittest time to corrupt a man’s wife is

speaker: ROMAN
text: when she’s fall’n out with her husband. Your noble

speaker: ROMAN
text: Tullus Aufidius will appear well in these wars, his

speaker: ROMAN
text: great opposer Coriolanus being now in no request

speaker: ROMAN
text: of his country.

speaker: VOLSCE
text: He cannot choose. I am most fortunate thus

speaker: VOLSCE
text: accidentally to encounter you. You have ended my

speaker: VOLSCE
text: business, and I will merrily accompany you home.

speaker: ROMAN
text: I shall between this and supper tell you most

speaker: ROMAN
text: strange things from Rome, all tending to the good

speaker: ROMAN
text: of their adversaries. Have you an army ready, say

speaker: ROMAN
text: you?

speaker: VOLSCE
text: A most royal one. The centurions and their

speaker: VOLSCE
text: charges, distinctly billeted, already in th’ entertainment,

speaker: VOLSCE
text: and to be on foot at an hour’s warning.

speaker: ROMAN
text: I am joyful to hear of their readiness and am

speaker: ROMAN
text: the man, I think, that shall set them in present action.

speaker: ROMAN
text: So, sir, heartily well met, and most glad of

speaker: ROMAN
text: your company.

speaker: VOLSCE
text: You take my part from me, sir. I have the most

speaker: VOLSCE
text: cause to be glad of yours.

speaker: ROMAN
text: Well, let us go together.
